awd_abstract_narration:
The Texas Association of Developing Colleges (TADC) is undertaking a data network planning grant in preparation for establishing a regional highspeed data network to support science, technology and engineering (STEM) research and education. The network will connect TADC and its five Historically Black Colleges and Universities (HBCU) members: Jarvis Christian College, Paul Quinn College, Texas College, Huston-Tillotson University, and Wiley College. It will be used to develop a deeper learning educational environment by bridging the gap between theory and practical utilization of technology. Access to gigabit research and education campus networking gives the African American students attending the member schools the opportunity to study in a next generation learning environment to acquire 21st century skills needed to advance professionally.

Currently, these under-resourced schools are not able to keep up with the rapid changes in campus cyberinfrastructure. They are lacking highspeed broadband for connecting to regional, national and international education and research needed to advance the knowledge of their students. Their campus information technology (IT) infrastructure is not capable of providing the capacity needed to meet the demands of their faculty, students, and administrators. Establishing the TADC regional network would set up a state-of-the-art Science DMZ between the member schools that will provide direct access to STEM education and research opportunities. Moreover, the faculty’s ability to compete for research and other grant opportunities would be greatly enhanced. The creation of the TADC regional network starts with this Planning Grant to collect information from each member school. The information will serve as the roadmap to guide future planning and proposals to establish gigabit  networking to five underserved HBCUs and TADC.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Texas Association of Developing Colleges

Project Outcome Report

1.1. Major Goals

As Princeton University and other Ivy League and Tier 1 schools form partnerships with HBCUs, private, small, liberal arts colleges and universities will be excluded from the prospective growth in the nation?s educational infrastructure in the absence of an enhanced Campus Cyberinfrastructure. Accordingly, the Texas Association of Developing Colleges (TADC) received an NSF planning grant. Through this NSF CC* Planning grant, TADC achieved each of its proposed goals. The Final Report describes the findings from a comprehensive assessment of the cyberinfrastructure fragilities of each of the five small, liberal arts HBCUs that comprise the Consortium on this grant.

1.2. The TADC?s Accomplishments Under Each of Their Five Goals

1.2.0. Identification of Needs

Via interviews, surveys, and a review of the cyberinfrastructure of each of the five HBCUs, the needs described below were identified.

1.2.1. Through the onsite academic program and IT system assessment of each

Consortium member, the planning grant revealed that the members of TADC have the collective STEM or STEM-related programs that drive the need for a strengthening of infrastructure. Despite the past receipt of more than $10 million collective dollars for their STEAM/Stem-related programs, severities of need exist but are unequally distributed across each of the five Consortium members. These areas of need had to be identified if strategies were to be implemented that lead to their reduction.

1.2.2. While CC-networking upgrades occurred across the Consortium members, such changes have been uneven and Texas College and Houston Tillotson University lag behind Jarvis Christian College, Paul Quinn, and Wiley in their need for cyberinfrastructure upgrades. This problem can be resolved by designing and implementing a TADC Regional Science DMZ design that will use a friction-free 10G and a TADS Regional Science DMZ network to serve all members. However, funding is needed for equipment upgrades to the cyber infrastructure of all partnering HBCUs, but in varying degrees. High-performance computing in combination with computational science and engineering is critical to undergraduate and graduate preparation in multiple science areas.

1.2.3. The SWOT analysis also revealed an unmet need for the writing and production of Governance materials to guide the use and selection of IT strategies by the members..

1.2.4. The Needs Assessment included the students served by the Consortium members.

The findings confirmed the need for written and other materials from the IT Division and/or a Specialist in this area for each member. It also revealed a need for Internet connectivity. It was revealed that only 14% of the students, had used computers for 120+ hours per week. A social marketing campaign is needed to address this need since this is less than two hours per day in a world that is becoming increasingly technological.

1.2.5. The Assessment also identified a highly critical need that is, perhaps, related to their status as small, liberal arts colleges. Specifically, research in the sciences requires a friction-free, high-speed, broadband internet rather than the general-purpose network design that the TADC Consortium members were using. These needs must be addressed so that STEM research can be expanded. Internet2 is desperately needed.

1.2.6. The analysis of need was not designed to propose that these HBCUs transform into STEM schools. However, one member, Texas College, is already experimenting with STEAM. It is recommended that a Regional Science DMZ be implemented so that the technology can be used in STEAM/STEM programs.

1.3. Recommendations

Other needs were also identified. Given the range of needs, the Planning Grant Final Report recommends that a Regional Science DMZ and the use of high-speed broadband connectivity would address most of the key needs and support the delivery of STEM courses, research, and other initiatives within the framework of these HBCUs. Science DMZ would also support the transfer of technology.

1.4. Recommendations are also made regarding the specific needs of each of the five HBCUs that form the TADC Consortium.

1.5. Intellectual Merit

The criticality of expanding the use of technology as a mechanism for the dissemination of academic existent and new knowledge has been confirmed not merely by the COVID-19 experience. Technology is an efficient and cost-effective methodology for the delivery of education and training once the necessary tools have been acquired.

1.6. Broader Impact

The broader impact ?of supplementing? the educational impact of the Consortium?s HBCUs is tremendous. An abundance of research reveals that advancing higher educational outcomes not only increases Gross Domestic Product, but higher education also contributes to every aspect of life in the U.S. and other countries from the quality of family life to decreases in crime and increases in life expectancy. The Assessment will allow the Consortium to maximize the contributions of each HBCU to the lives of their enrollees, their communities, and our nation.

The NSF CC* Planning Grant Final Report 2022 describes these and other findings.
